I am an Astrophysics major (although this knowledge isn't from a class), we don't currently know of any stars large enough to create a GRB that are pointed at us and close enough to cause mass extinction level damage. The closest possibility is WR 104, a Wolf Rayet star (basically a star that's so big and powerful that it's blasting off a sizeable fraction of its mass in its solar wind, although there are other traits), which is pointed vaguely towards us and very large, but it's not certain that it will create a GRB (one originating in a high metallicity star would be unusual) and only certain attempts to measure its axis have shown it as anywhere near pointed at us, other methods have found it pointed well to the side and therefore not a threat.

Short duration GRB, which are created by colliding neutron stars, would be harder to identify as those are small enough that us failing to detect them is a real possibility at the ranges close enough to be a threat, but those are even more rare, and release less energy than long duration ones.

Lol no it's not the ozone layer that protects things on the surface of the Earth from gamma rays. The ozone layer is opaque to hard ultraviolet, basically electromagnetic radiation that is almost x-rays but not quite. The sort of UV light that erases EPROMs and makes you go blind if you see even a tiny bit of it because it causes cataracts to form on your eyes. No, gamma rays are just stopped by the atmosphere in general. Which is somewhat opaque to it, but having a few miles of atmosphere is enough.

My sister theorized the events that caused the 3-4am fires (not the arson/power/lighting ones) up and down the pacific US coast Sept. 7th 2020 were mainly caused by 15 mile wide bursts from another star system possibly a neutron star no bigger than 20 miles in diameter, and if we took the time to trace the NASA star charts dating to the same morning, it would show extreme activity from said constellation point as a bright anomaly or artifact. Others have thrown around conspiracies involving DoD DEW equipment, but the array of locations wouldn't make sense unless it was natural, but also not make sense unless it was massive, due to their preciseness and exact timing across several states. No witnesses inside it would survive, and external viewers would not see the light of the rays, as they would be outside visible spectrum. Due to the speed of neutron stars, and the rotation of and revolution of Earth as it deviates the angle, it would only last mere seconds. Because of this, satellite footage would be hard to recover of the event. Also, it is worth noting that satellite footage of that night was edited and had a large strait artifact cloven over the pacific. Not saying we got hit by any gamma ray bursts but, maybe nature is more perfect with all its little imperfections than we once realized. Perhaps the sun itself protects us from the nasty ones, and every now and then its solar cycles slip up and let a nasty one through, thus creating the mass extinction event 450 million years ago. But, we don't even have to go back that far in history to observe existing hints at extra solar activity devastating life on Earth. We don't even have to go past human time. On the bright side, we're way more likely to suddenly die out from overtoxification from PFOAs within 2 generations, or get wiped out by an overly friendly comet that came in from outside our solar system, where it is not yet visible to us while cold, or an out of control flu virus, or nuclear war. My bet is on a rogue blackhole warping the solar system slowly into a compact space, redshifting everything until spaghettification intensifies. It would look a lot like the bible actually. The stars would fall out of the sky, the sun would go out and the moon would turn red and go out too. Everything would get so uncomfortable, and then all at once, after seeming eons of time. bvvvttt. Gone.

Einstein's famous equation, E=mc^2 is wrong otherwise garbage also can be used to make nuclear bombs as long as it is matter or it has mass. Energy and matter can't interchange one another according to Einstein's famous equation. One must have photons before one can emit out photons. Photons are particles and they have mass. All forms of EMWs are dynamic photons per volume per time in different saturations. I do agree that long gamma burst is due to supernova explosion as a result of the nascent formation of a neutron star or a black hole where all atoms of dying dense star will be eventually reduced to quarks or preons respectively under its own tremendous weight. It will be quite awhile for entire dying star to eventually turning into a lump of quarks or preons respectively. Thus, the gamma burst will last for awhile.. On the other hand, short gamma burst is likely due to mergence of two neutron stars into a black holes. Quarks still contain some sizeable remnant of photons. When quarks reduce to preons, there are still sizeable amount of photons to be dissipated out before neutron stars turned into a black  hole. When two black holes merge to become a larger black hole, there wont be even a short gamma burst taken place because superstructures of black holes don't contain any photons at all. But sucking all celestial bodies within the accretion disk of black holes before merging them (by reducing them from atoms to preons) into a part of a larger black hole will dissipate out tremendous dynamic photons in the form of short gamma burst. Some supernova explosions had already taken place within Milky Way in the past since NASA discovered there are presence of some gigantic black holes within the center of Milky Way. Glad that we (our ancestors) still managed to survive despite of long gamma bursts near our vicinity in the past.If you are interested in real discoveries, I would recommend you to read my book, The Unification Theory- Volume One and you will be amazed with lots of new, interesting discoveries. GRBs happen when a black/white hole sucks in an entire star and shoots all it's light directly at us. Think Einstein-Rosen Bridge where the ass end is pointed right at us.

We can't see/detect gamma ray bursts that are not pointed directly at us.

The video does a great job of explaining the inverse square law of light. (The principal holds true for gravity and electromagnetism.)

When a supernova occurs, the light is dispersed in all directions more or less equally. As that light expands outward it gets more and more diluted, as if it were trying to fill up the entire Galaxy.

A gamma ray burst is shot out in a very narrow beam in only one direction. The inverse square law of light doesn't apply. That is why they appear brighter than the entire universe.

Fortunately, only roughly half of us will die instantly and without warning. Gamma ray bursts are strong but short, and Earth is thick enough - so those lucky enough to be on the other side will have plenty of time (hours, maybe days) till ozone depletion and other effects spread to their  side of the planet. Plenty of time to buy lots of sunscreen. Biosphere damage is another matter, but even then, it'll take years or centuries till the effects are felt globally, once again, giving plenty of time to mitigate the damage. Luckily, Earth being round, no single GRB can take out all centers of technological civilization in one flash (though hit on the North hemisphere would be the most problematic).

A GRB has to go off close to us to kill us.
Meaning it won't kill us. Both ways in which a GRB may be created require supermassive stars since only a supermassive star can become a supernova/neutron star.
Supermassive stars, however, have a relatively short lifespan. Due to their mass they burn up rather quickly. Right now there are no supermassive stars close to us. And there won't be in the future, as there aren't any areas nearby where new stars can be born.
So I'd say we're pretty safe - until that Galaxy crashes into us perhaps.

One cannot measure distances of greater than about 25 light-years using parallax since we don't know EXACTLY where (not only does the Earth go around the sun, the sun orbits the galactic center, etc. so determining exactly where Earth was 180 days ago is all the more difficult) the Earth was sixth months ago using the Earth's ORBIT around the sun as the base of the triangle. Just ONE light-year has an angle of ONLY 0.017 degrees already! If u think Red Shift measures/accurately gauges distances 2 distant objects, u need 2 know that red shift is QUANTIZED (only at certain energy levels), absolutely ruling out the Dopper Effect explanation, may b caused by tired light, (Light may lose energy naturally as it travels and remember that since light has mass, it is affected by other objects with mass. A solar sail works because light has momentum and therefore mass. If you believe light has energy, and energy is mass according to Einstein, then you believe light has mass.) objects moving @ right angles to us, & when gravity is acting on an object. There's this object moving TOWARDS us that is still red-shifted!!! There's this pair of objects connected with radically different redshifts that proves the big bang wrong. In addition, in the Virgo Cluster of galaxies, near the center, where the velocities are extremely high, the red-shift is somehow washed out. This strongly implies that strong motion DESTROYS the redshift, instead of creating it. A galaxy has even been measured to have a DECREASE of one quantization in redshift, which should be impossible if the universe is expanding and the redshift is due to the doppler effect. YouTube: Stretching the Heavens: A New Cosmology. Google Science vs Evolution Pathlights. We can barely make out PLUTO with our best telescopes and yet we are told astronomers have detected a planet 1,300 or so light-years away?! Think about it. The object MAY be thousands of light-years away but we cannot measure those distances. We are simply TOO TINY, to put it humbly. And yes, there may be no such thing as deep space. Perhaps the "far away" objects are just super-tiny. It's possible. How could we know the difference? The Cosmic Background Radiation is much too cold to have come from the supposed Big Bang. It actually comes from stars. The heavens shall pass away with a great noise... interesting how from a biblical perspective, the big bang is in the future, where the heavens will be passed AWAY, instead of in the past, where it supposedly created the universe.

Out of curiosity I did a rough hand calculation using numbers quoted in this video and found that the worst-case mean time between (potential) GRBs that could hit the earth and be of existential danger is somewhere around 44 billion years.

Based on some assumptions (guessing at the standard deviation from the average GRB event rate) and accounting for errors (had to make assumptions here too), further calculation shows that the probability of such an Earth-destroying event happening once within our universe's lifetime would be between 2% and 10%.That's worst-case roughly 0.000000077% chance of occurring in a person's lifetime.

Here is where gamma ray bursts really come from! : A black hole collects all the nearby matter until none is left close enough to be captured, all other matter being pulled on more strongly by other masses. So the finished black hole sits there collecting LIGHT ! The super hot plasma boiling inside expands as it's temperature increases from this captured light. While it's mass will increase slightly from the mass of this light being added, it's not much by comparison to the mass from the matter in the plasma, and consequently the event horizon doesn't expand much. BUT The surface of the plasma ball does expand from the increase in temperature. Eventually the surface of the plasma will be equal in size to the event horizon and some will leak out. Now the mass inside is a bit lower, and the event horizon shrinks accordingly. Now ALOT of matter is no longer inside and the event horizon shrinks even more. See where this going? In a fraction of a second the super black hole explodes into  a very big ball of rapidly expanding plasma which cools and condenses into a galaxy. How long would this process take? Quite a while. How much time does it have? Infinite. I could be wrong though:)

This might be a bit nitpick-y, but just a minor correction regarding 1:20-1:25, which states, "Ionizing radiation is energetic enough to break apart atomic bonds."

This is not quite right because ionization is not the breaking of atomic bonds (i.e. the bonds between atoms), but rather the knocking off of an electron from an atom (or molecule). Electrons are not attached with atomic bonds, so knocking one off wouldn't be breaking atomic bonds. For ionization to occur, a substance only needs electrons to knock off, therefore ionization can occur whether there are atomic bonds present or not. As an example, ionization frequently happens in non-molecules (like atomic hydrogen) where no atomic bonds exist. A better way to describe it than what's in the video might be, "Ionizing radiation is energetic enough to kick/knock electrons off of atoms."

Again, this is very minor and the visuals were accurate, it was just the audio that was an issue for me. I love all your videos and I show them to my students all the time! :)

You keep referring to the ozone layer. Indeed, ozone is opaque to frequencies in the UV and above, absorbing rather than transmitting them and re-radiating them eventually as heat. However, the oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere are also opaque to frequencies starting the the soft x-rays, and so they do the lion's share of blocking gamma rays. At sea level, where ozone is exceedingly rare, gamma rays are still attentuated by 1/2 for every 200 meters of air they pass through, or by a factor of 250 per mile. It was safe facing the prompt gamma from nuclear blasts at a range of 6 miles, as was often done in the 50s.

Indeed, if the proverbial 4000 ly GRb did hit us, the gammas would almost all be absorbed by the atmosphere. That keeps us from frying on the surface, but it also destroys all the ozone on the exposed half of the globe, and the solar UV climbs by a factor of 50%. That's what kills us all.

When you calculate it's degradation over distance using Inverse-square law (and add to that the constant values that it's denser in it's center compared to it's edges) then we know that if it's to harm us it has to be close by to do us any real harm. Yes it could happen but, the poles of the potential candidates has to face us pretty much dead on (+ - 2 degrees approximately) to cause a mass extinction event. the reason why this is unlikely is that most stars in our galaxy tends to form poles that goes in the same parallel direction because the galaxy is spinning (not going in to detail because it would take to long to explain). There is exception to this, just look at Uranus, so yes there is chance it would happen but it's astronomically small.

Dear Kurzgesagt,

thank you for your video on this astronomical phenomenon, I do enjoy your production. However, I have to disagree with your description of the interaction of gamma rays in the atmosphere and the related description of the mechanism of damage of the ozone layer.

It is true that a large part of the cosmic gamma ray flux is absorbed in the region of the atmosphere (20-45 km, stratosphere) that contains the so called ozone layer. Nonetheless, the ozone layer is a metaphorical term - the stratosphere contains over an altitude of tens of kilometers only a small concentration of ozone. If all the ozone from the stratosphere were to be compressed to surface air pressure, the gas layer would be only about 3 mm thick. It is not actually the ozone layer itself that absorbs the gamma rays, but mostly oxygen and nitrogen molecules that make up the bulk of the stratosphere. Very few ozone molecules are impacted. These also get ionized by the interactions with gamma rays, but in low fluxes of gamma rays this has no impact on the concentration ozone. However, during a catastrophic event - such as a near supernova explosion or an illumination of a gamma ray burst - the high radiation dose delivered to the upper atmosphere would excite and ionize a siginificant fraction of the bulk air in the stratosphere, which would lead to the creation of large quantities of different nitrogen oxides (NOx). These NOx molecules act as catalyzers for ozone breakup. Ozone is actually regenerated fairly quickly in the atmosphere (in days), because it is rapidly generated by UV-photolysis of molecular oxygen; however, the presence of NOx molecules in the stratosphere would decrease the steady-state concentration of ozone. The long-lasting damage to the ozone layer then would be caused by the long residence time (years) of NOx molecules in the stratosphere, similarly to our current issues with chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) gases.

Reading for more insight: https://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0211361

With best regards,
Martin Precek, Ph.D.

Well you could survive a gamma burst if you were in an underground bunker completely covered with lead.. but you would have these possible outcomes:

1. you'd suffocate
2. The lead would poison you
3. you would die of panicking (i.e. heart attack, stroke)
4. it would take thousands of years for the uranium 238 to be broken down so old age
5. suicide
6. you wouldn't have the bunker in the first place
7. etc. etc

but, the reality is, we have a very little chance of being struck by a gamma ray in OUR lifetime anyhow.. by the time one hit, science may have become so advanced to:

1. prevent it
2. find other planets to inhabit
3. humans can not evolve, but adapt to being able to handle the radioactivity
4. you get the point

Hello Kurzgesagt! I really admire you and I love the work that you do! I'd like to share something rather personal with you. Something I've been holding onto for about 2 years now and I have to tell you this now. So, please allow me to elaborate so by the time your done reading my comment, you'll know why.. Firstly, I am a deaf man but I haven't always been deaf! You see, I was born with a horrible disease called Ménière's and after me fighting and battling with it for 23 years of my life, it finally took my hearing from me.. I knew eventually I'd lose my hearing before I was 30 years old, due to the aggressive progression of it but during my last year of hearing, I tried so much to listen to as much of the things I loved because the only way I would be able to hear again.. was.. to relive my memories.. My sister has helped me so much through my depression and what she started doing for me - and even still to this very day - she writes down videos for me in my notebook and then I'll try to read and watch the video the best I can because sadly, the YouTube Captions are worthless. That is how I found you. I especially fell in love with you're work because in that field, making a deaf person hear again is possible and I long so badly to hear again. It saddens me that if I ever meet a woman and have kids, I'll never hear their voices.. It saddens me even more deeply I can't here my mom's voice no more or even my dad's.. I never realized how ungrateful I really was with my life.. How I took things for granted and how I long to change my past because now I know, what it means to be appreciative!! You sadly don't appreciate something until you don't have it no more.. I sadly, learn't the hard way. So, for watching your videos for about 2 years now, it has really helped me so much through my depression.. in ways you probably wouldn't understand.. I'm always so excited when you release a new video because, I love to LEARN! And one last thing before I end this, a few weeks ago, my Doctor diagnosed me with Endocrine Cancer but I am still waiting on the official results.These last few years, I was slowly getting out of my depression but getting that news, really.. really brought me down..i don't want to go blind too!! i don't want to die either.. So, I needed to get this off my chest because who knows, I might be dead in a few months, I don't know. I was never one to express my self but all I have had since I went deaf, was the YouTube Community and I am just thanking all the ones that has helped me through this that didn't even know they we're even there for me! I know my comment will disappear with all the others and that's OK!! At least I know I took my time to write this for ya! Thanks for everything and thanks for being there for me, when you didnt even know you was.. goodbye friend. bye bye now and remember, rock on!!

Amazing video guys, but big inaccuracy. Gamma rays aren't absorbed by the Ozone Layer the way UV light is.

Gamma rays are absorbed by the atmosphere primarily via a process called pair production. The gamma ray photon spontaneously turns into an electron-positron pair (positron is an anti-electron). The electron and positron interact with electric fields from the surrounding air molecules, get decelerated and emit photons (hence losing energy). These new photons then pair produce in turn, and this process continues anew, the number of 'daughter particles' doubling at each stage. From a single gamma-ray photon you get billions of high energy particles cascading down the atmosphere in an 'air shower'. They increase in number until the particles reach an energy threshold where they lose all their energy by ionising the surrounding air, and the shower dissipates.

Astronomers actually observe the highest energy gamma rays by measuring the showers they cause in the atmosphere and trying to reconstruct the energy and direction of the original gamma-ray photon. Lowering energy gamma-rays are measured by satellites directly (i.e. the Fermi Space Telescope).

Basically the gamma-ray absorption (aka attenuation or extinction) is proportional to the amount of atmosphere it passes through, it's not dependent on any specific layer. UV light is absorbed completely differently, the UV photons hit ozone molecules and their energy goes into breaking up the ozone (ozone is a molecule made of 3 oxygen molecules 03) into an oxygen molecule (O2) and a free oxygen ion (O+).You were correct through in saying that a gamma-ray burst could destroy the ozone layer and leave the Earth's surface exposed to life-killing UV radiation.
